trial_identification.studytitle: Effectiveness of splinting post Dupuytrens contracture release
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effectiveness of splinting for improving finger range of motion and function post Dupuytrens contracture release

interventions.interventions: Night extension splinting for three months post operatively.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Post surgery range of motion measured by the combination of metacarpophalangeal joint (MCPJ) and proximal interphalangeal joint (PIPJ) extension of the little finger using a standard finger goniometer

secondaryOutcome.outcome: *total active flexion of the operated fingers - measured using a finger goniometer
*composite finger flexion measured in centimeters from the distal palmar crease to the mail fold of the finger..
* grip strength - measured using a Jamar dynamometer
*hand function - measured using the Disabilities of Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) validated questionnaire.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Dupuytren's Contracture Release (DCR) on one or more fingers. Attended hand therapy within 10 days of DCR
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patient not attending 2 or more consecutive hand therapy appointments K-wiring of PIP joint intra-operatively.

trial_design.concealment: Randomisation will be done by selecting a random envelope with group allocation concealed in it

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Centre for Clinical Research & effective practice (CCRep)

fundingsource.fundingname: Centre for Clinical Research & effective practice (CCRep)

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
This randomised controlled trial will evaluate the clinical outcomes from a group of patients post Dupuytrens contracture surgery that have two different management programmes.
The aim of the study is to determine the effect of splinting or not splinting following release of Dupuytrens contracture on finger range of movement and function.
ethicsAndSummary.publication:
The Effect of Night Extension Orthoses Following Surgical Release of Dupuytren Contracture: A Single- Center, Randomized, Controlled Trial.
Julie Collis, MSc (Hons), Shirley Collocott, BSc, Wayne Hing, PhD, Edel Kelly, MSc (Hons) J Hand Surg 2013;38A:12851294
